summary: Oligodendrogliomas are a type of glioma believed to originate from oligodendrocytes or glial precursor cells. They primarily occur in adults but are also found in children, comprising about 5% of all central nervous system tumors. They are characterized by specific genetic alterations, including IDH mutations and 1p/19q co-deletion, which are associated with chemosensitivity and improved prognosis.
causes: NJDS gene mutation (69% correlation in one study)
Irradiation of pituitary adenoma (single case report)
symptoms: Headaches associated with increased intracranial pressure
Neurological deficits (e.g., visual loss, motor weakness, cognitive decline)
diagnosis: Molecular diagnostics (e.g., IDH mutation testing, 1p/19q co-deletion analysis)
treatments: Symptomatic treatment (anticonvulsants for seizures, steroids for brain swelling)
